% For centered entries: 
% Allow line breaks with \\ in specialcells
\newcommand{\specialcell}[2][c]{%
\begin{tabular}[#1]{@{}c@{}}#2\end{tabular}
}

% *****************************************************************
% siunitx
% *****************************************************************
\newcommand{\sym}[1]{\rlap{#1}} % Thanks to Joseph Wright & David Carlisle

\usepackage{siunitx}
    \sisetup{
        detect-mode,
        group-digits            = false,
        input-symbols           = ( ) [ ] - +,
        tight-spacing		= true,
        table-align-text-post   = false,
        input-signs             = ,
        }   

% Packages for tables
\usepackage{booktabs}% Pretty tables
\usepackage{threeparttablex}% For Notes below table

% Character substitution that prints brackets and the minus symbol in text mode. Thanks to David Carlisle
\def\yyy{%
  \bgroup\uccode`\~\expandafter`\string-%
  \uppercase{\egroup\edef~{\noexpand\text{\llap{\textendash}\relax}}}%
  \mathcode\expandafter`\string-"8000 }

\def\xxxl#1{%
\bgroup\uccode`\~\expandafter`\string#1%
\uppercase{\egroup\edef~{\noexpand\text{\noexpand\llap{\string#1}}}}%
\mathcode\expandafter`\string#1"8000 }

\def\xxxr#1{%
\bgroup\uccode`\~\expandafter`\string#1%
\uppercase{\egroup\edef~{\noexpand\text{\noexpand\rlap{\string#1}}}}%
\mathcode\expandafter`\string#1"8000 }

\def\textsymbols{\xxxl[\xxxr]\xxxl(\xxxr)\yyy}


% *****************************************************************
% Estout related things
% *****************************************************************
\let\estinput=\input % define a new input command so that we can still flatten the document

\newcommand{\estwide}[3]{
        \vspace{.75ex}{
            \textsymbols% Note the added command here
            \begin{tabular*}
            {\textwidth}{@{\hskip\tabcolsep\extracolsep\fill}l*{#2}{#3}}
            \toprule
            \estinput{#1}
            \bottomrule
            \addlinespace[.75ex]
            \end{tabular*}
            }
        }   

\newcommand{\estauto}[3]{
        \vspace{.75ex}{
            \textsymbols% Note the added command here
            \begin{tabular}{l*{#2}{#3}}
            \toprule
            \estinput{#1}
            \bottomrule
            \addlinespace[.75ex]
            \end{tabular}
            }
        }

% *****************************************************************
% Custom subcaptions
% *****************************************************************
% Note/Source/Text after Tables
% The new approach using threeparttables to generate notes that are the exact width of the table.
\newcommand{\Figtext}[1]{%
    \begin{tablenotes}[para,flushleft]
    \hspace{6pt}
    \hangindent=1.75em
    #1
    \end{tablenotes}
    }
\newcommand{\Fignote}[1]{\Figtext{\emph{Note:~}~#1}}
\newcommand{\Figsource}[1]{\Figtext{\emph{Source:~}~#1}}
\newcommand{\Starnote}{\Figtext{* p < 0.1, ** p < 0.05, *** p < 0.01. Standard errors in parentheses.}}% Add significance note with \starnote

\usepackage{changepage}

\usepackage{bbm}
\usepackage{bm}

\begin{longtable}[l]{l>{\raggedright}m{16cm}}
\toprule 
\selectlanguage{american}%
\textbf{\scriptsize{}Index Variables}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\midrule 
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Value of non-land assets (USD)}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}Total value (in 2012 USD PPP) of all non-land assets
owned by the household, including savings, livestock, durable goods,
and metal roofs.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Non-durable expenditure (USD)}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}Total monthly spending (in 2012 USD PPP) on non-durables,
including food, temptation goods, medical care, education expenditures,
and social expenditures. }\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Total revenue, monthly (USD)}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}Total monthly revenue (in 2012 USD PPP) from all household
enterprises, including revenue from agriculture, stock and flow revenue
from animals owned by the household, and revenue from all non-farm
enterprises owned by any household member.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Food security index}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}A standardized weighted average of the (negatively coded)
number of times household adults and children skipped meals, went
whole days without food, had to eat cheaper or less preferred food,
had to rely on others for food, had to purchase food on credit, had
to hunt for or gather food, had to beg for food, or went to sleep
hungry in the preceding week; a (negatively coded) indicator for whether
the respondent went to sleep hungry in the preceding week; the (positively
coded) number of times household members ate meat or fish in the preceding
week; (positively coded) indicators for whether household members
ate at least two meals per day, ate until content, had enough food
for the next day, and whether the respondent ate protein in the last
24 hours; and the (positively coded) proportion of household members
who ate protein in the last 24 hours, and proportion of children who
ate protein in the last 24 hours.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Health index}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}A standardized weighted average of the (negatively coded)
proportion of household adults who were sick or injured in the last
month, the (negatively coded) proportion of household children who
were sick or injured in the last month, the (positively coded) proportion
of sick or injured family members for whom the household could afford
treatment, the (positively coded) proportion of illnesses for which
a doctor was consulted, the (positively coded) proportion of newborns
who were vaccinated, the (positively coded) proportion of children
below age 14 who received a health checkup in the preceding six months,
the (negatively coded) proportion of children under 5 who died in
the preceding year, and a children's anthropometrics index consisting
of BMI, height-for-age, weight-for-age, and upper arm circumference
relative to WHO development benchmarks.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Education index}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}A standardized weighted average of the proportion of
household children enrolled in school and the amount spent by the
household on educational expenses per child. }\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Psychological well-being index}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}A standardized weighted average of their (negatively
coded) scores on the CES-D scale \shortcite{radloff_ces-d_1977},
a custom worries questionnaire (negatively coded), Cohen's stress
scale \shortcite{cohen_global_1983} (negatively coded), their response
to the the World Values Survey happiness and life satisfaction questions,
and their log cortisol levels adjusted for confounders (negatively
coded). }\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Female Empowerment Index}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}A standardized weighted average of a measure of two
other indices, a violence and an attitude index. The violence index
is a weighted standardized average of the frequency with which the
respondent reports having been physically, sexually, or emotionally
abused by her husband in the preceding six months; the attitude index
is a weighted standardized average of a measure of the respondent\textquoteright s
view of the justifiability of violence against women, and a scale
of male-focused attitudes.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\midrule
\selectlanguage{american}%
\textbf{\scriptsize{}Psychological Wellbeing}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Log cortisol (no controls)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}Log of salivary cortisol levels in nm/l, taken as the
average of level across two samples.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Log cortisol (with controls)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}Residuals of an OLS regression of the log-transformed
cortisol levels on dummies for having ingested food, drinks, alcohol,
nicotine, or medications in the two hours preceding the interview,
for having performed vigorous physical activity on the day of the
interview, and for the time elapsed since waking, rounded to the next
full hour}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Depression (CESD)}\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized total of the score from the 20 elements
of the CES-D questionnaire \shortcite{radloff_ces-d_1977}.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Worries}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized total of the score from the 16 elements
of a custom worries questionnaire.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Stress (Cohen)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized total of score from 4 elements of Cohen's
stress scale \shortcite{cohen_global_1983}.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Happiness (WVS)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized numerical response to the World Values
Survey happiness question: Taking all things together, would you say
you are \textquotedblleft very happy\textquotedblright{} (1), \textquotedblleft quite
happy\textquotedblright{} (2), \textquotedblleft not very happy\textquotedblright{}
(3), or \textquotedblleft not at all happy\textquotedblright{} (4)?}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Life satisfaction (WVS)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized numerical response to the World Values
Survey life satisfaction question: All things considered, how satisfied
are you with your life as a whole these days on a scale of 1 to 10?
(1= very dissatisfied...10= very satisfied)}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Trust (WVS)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized numerical response to the World Values
Survey life satisfaction question: Generally speaking, would you say
that most people can be trusted (1) or that you need to be very careful
in dealing with people (2)?}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Locus of control}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized weighted average of the total score
on Rotter's locus of control questionnaire and the numerical response
the World Values Survey locus of control question (Some people believe
that individuals can decide their own destiny, while others think
that it is impossible to escape a predetermined fate. Please tell
me which comes closest to your view on this scale on which 1 means
\textquotedblleft everything in life is determined by fate\textquotedblright{}
and 10 means \textquotedblleft people shape their fate themselves.\textquotedblright )
Higher scores indicate a more internal locus of control.}\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Optimism (Scheier)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized total score on the 6 question Scheier
optimism questionnaire. }\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Self-esteem (Rosenberg)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The standardized total score on the 10 question Rosenberg
optimism questionnaire. }\selectlanguage{english}%
\tabularnewline
\selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%
 & \selectlanguage{american}%
\selectlanguage{english}%

\multirow{1}{*}{\selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}\ Food total (USD)}\selectlanguage{english}%
} & \selectlanguage{american}%
{\scriptsize{}The combined monthly total (in 2012 USD PPP) of all
spending on food by the household and the value of all food produced
from agriculture and livestock that was consumed by the household
(calculated as the monthly average of total production in the last
year). }\selectlanguage{english}%

members of the household on all cereal grains, flours, breads, pastas,
cakes and biscuits. }\selectlanguage{english}%

\selectlanguage{american}%
